topic.title: Mathematics of Public Key Cryptography
topic.body:
Written by an active researcher in the topic, this book aims precisely to explain the main ideas and techniques behind public key cryptography, from both historical and future development perspectives. Because of the abundance of examples, proofs and exercises, it is suitable as a textbook for an advanced course, or even for self-study. For more advanced readers, it is a basic reference for crucial topics such as the Pollard algorithms, elliptic curves and isogenies, algebraic tori, and lattices.

topic.title: COVID19 Treatment Protocol
topic.body:
"Please circulate as widely as possible. It is crucial that every pulmonologist, every critical care doctor and nurse, every hospital administrator, every public health official receive this information immediately."

(https://www.evms.edu/media/evms_public/departments/internal_medicine/EVMS_Critical_Care_COVID-19_Protocol.pdf)

While there is no high level evidence that this cocktail is effective; it is cheap, safe and should be readily available. So what is there to lose?
• Vitamin C 500 mg BID and Quercetin 250-500 mg BID
• Zinc 75-100 mg/day (acetate, gluconate or picolinate). Zinc lozenges are preferred. After 1-2months, reduce the dose to 30-50 mg/day. 
• Melatonin (slow release): Begin with 0.3mg and increase as tolerated to 1-2 mg at night 
• Vitamin D3 1000-4000 u/day (optimal dose unknown). Likely that those with baseline low 25-OH vitamin D levels and those > living at 40o latitude will benefit the most.

topic.title: Croquet.io a ZeroNet like Appdev platform
topic.body:
[Croquet.io](croquet.io)

FAQ
What is Croquet?
Croquet is a software system for creating multiuser digital experiences on the web. It lets you build real time multiuser apps without writing server code, or deploying servers.

How does Croquet work?
When a Croquet app starts, it automatically connects to a nearby cloud-based reflector in our worldwide fleet. The reflector mirrors user inputs to a virtual computer running on each user’s local client. Croquet makes sure these virtual computers stay in bit-identical synchronization. Every user has the same shared experience, even though no central server is coordinating things.

What is a reflector?
A reflector is a special type of public server located in the cloud. It's very simple and lightweight. All it does is forward events from Croquet clients to other clients that are connected to the same multiuser session. Reflectors are completely generic. Any app can use any reflector. This means that it's easy for us to deploy lots of reflectors across the globe, so everyone is close to a low-latency multiuser experience.

ZN is mostly small files.
Replication is inefficient. Stores all accessed data at every node.
Dispersing bits of files across many nodes in a way they can be reconstructed (using erasure codes) is much more efficient.
Secret sharing systems use these principles: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_sharing
http://ansrlab.cse.cuhk.edu.hk/software/cdstore/
Look at parts of IBM GPFS
And the Mojette Transform - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojette_Transform
Lastly, this may be of particular interest (python): https://github.com/tahoe-lafs/zfec

> [styromaniac](#comment_82_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): User submissions aren't uploaded on any ZeroNet site. The site only lists the file. ZeroNet points to the IP addresses and port numbers of users who have the file chunks where a connection is possible and sends copies of the chunks to peers requesting the file while both are online. The peer who clicked to download the file isn't a seeder until they have all chunks of the file. [...]

That is the problem indeed. I do know about BT and how ZN works. 
What I asked earlier is about IFS, which I don't know. But you didn't feel like sharing at the time. That's ok.
Now I understand that IFS is not a data storing server, but simply a tracker like in BT.
It would be interesting to have a crawler mode for IFS and anyone else running a supernode that is willing to cache things on upload (like 0net.io).
If it were a data dispersal based system, the initial upload would need to complete somewhere temporarily to avoid the source disappearing and leaving behind a dead link. Then as more users come by, a small chunk+ec data could be distributed to them, even if they don't download the file. As the 'seeding' reaches a certain threshold of nodes (visitors), the temporary file is freed, and now a swarm of potential small chunks exists (along with the full downloads), where all don't need to be downloaded, because of a good error correction algorithm that can reconstruct any missing or slow chunks at its leisure. (See http://steinwurf.com/products/kodo.html)

1540601928_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
Let's have a round of applause. They are finally catching on to the fact that encryption without a formal trust hierarchy is a hell of a lot more secure than no encryption. And that maybe the subject line should be encrypted.  They are even figuring out that key distribution should be built into the protocol, or at least hacked on in a semi-transparent way that doesn't require any effort by the user.

Why this wasn't done 20 years ago when Eudora became popular I have no idea. I also don't understand why HTTP does not default to self-signed encryption if no cert is available. Man in the middle is hard and you can get caught. Listening is safe.

Now if they made this the default in Outlook, Thunderbird and whatever else people are using nowadays they'd be getting somewhere.

1541648221_1DJqae3bJR9Dz7f5QryWXywv92Jqm.body:
Current AI has not exceeded the intelligence of a fruit fly or worm.
It is horribly flawed in many ways.


The math is broken and incomplete. 65+ years ago, shortcuts were taken to approximate things. (no CPU)
The statistics coming from math is only able to deal with independent random variables. (non real world)
The data must be changed into i.i.d. form randomized before algo can take a look. (non real world)
The real world is all dependent, so the models we generate are pure fiction based on randomized data and independent variables. (we can't do dependence)


You only get to see the rare achievements in the news, not how many failures it takes to get there. Makes it look like anyone can do it. (you can't)


The truth is that AI is not A nor I, today. It's just clever linear algebra. It has a very narrow purpose. (clustering & probability)
AFAIK there is no AGI since we don't have algorithms that are scalable and don't use back propagation.


Any algorithm that is feed-forward and uses back propagation is doomed because it ends up an incoherent black box that can't be trusted, audited or understood. It can tell you that pic is a cat, and sometimes it will tell you it's a bus. You don't know when it's going horribly wrong and all that needs to change is a pixel or two. (totally can't trust it)


I work at a company that has solved parts of this problem, but it's relatively unknown still. We can perfectly explain the black box above given the model. Not even DARPA can do this yet. This is crucial for trust and explainability.


Most AI should not be called AI, because AI is not a thing, or a technology, it's actually a concept.
y=x is a simple "AI" because it predicts the value of x given any value of y.
if x==1 then do y is also an example of an expert system which is a category of AI.


What we're all talking about is ML which is its own category in the hierarchy of AI.
DL is a sub class of ML, which stacks many ML models and transformations together.
ML is relatively simple, DL is a spaghetti mess.


People like to call their chat bot, app & oracle AGI, but it's really just a collection of a few different ML or DL systems together. A few narrow focused systems bunched together with smoke and mirrors to make it seem like AGI.


If and when someone does create an AGI, they may not know it until it starts doing it's own thing at breakneck speed.


tl;dr We currently don't have the math, statistics or algorithm technology for achieving a proper AI concept, not to mention AGI.

> [moor](#comment_47_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): [...] I'm more excited about neuroscience and the fields based on it, where the conceptual model is more likely to take place before mathematical models comes in.

Yes, our technology is based on neuroscience.

There is plenty of literature based on robotics and intelligent systems conceptually.

> [moor](#comment_48_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): what do you think about connectome and the like?

That's like looking at squiggly lines from space. It could be a road, it could be a river or a crack, we don't know.
It's interesting to look at and think about, but it's all speculative so far. It may be useful data in the future, but it's too early to tell.

This can also fall into the category of: why do we bother creating machines that mimic the human brain?

We don't understand most of the brain or ourselves as a biological machine. Why would we want machines in the same way? We wouldn't. We need machines to do things for us in predictable and correct ways better than we can ourselves. Not the other way around ;-)

I'll still read about it, even though it's mostly media hype and a source of humor. 

Like the time they claimed a rat brain was uploaded to the cloud, when in reality they thinly sliced a rat brain, took pictures of the slices and uploaded the images. It's clearly not a functional rat brain in the cloud no matter how you slice it. (pun intended)

> [moor](#comment_49_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): [...] will these AI or AGI, which we want to assists us with scientific research, etc, have or need consciousness?

In short, no.
One can create a framework, but not the emergent behavior or the spark that makes consciousness. (so far)
We appear to be trying to brute force it without sufficient understanding. (not good)

Even if you could 3D print a brain, it wouldn't be much more than a lump of stuff you can't use as a brain, let alone a vessel to upload to, or a virtual brain. Other organs are much simpler.

In fact, I've worked on a storage system that is **so** reliable that one day it might be suitable for upload of a digitized mind, and it's so resilient and bit perfect to preserve it's exabytes of stored information, yet the human mind is lossy, doesn't perfectly remember things, and functions in a completely different associative manner. The storage system exceeds the brain in this case, yet it's not required for a brain. (ex: Westworld)

Like I mentioned before, current systems are just a bunch of linear algebra. Do you need to have a talking hammer to build things? No. You just need it to do things that are not easy for you.

So it's more about augmentation, and working with these systems than having them replace  us.

We humans are so myopic, confused and blind, we assume things we see, hear and feel are all there is, when there is so much more we simply ignore because we can't prove it. Thinking we understand a biological machine if far from understanding ourselves and all the things we don't see. (spiritual, mystical, other)

We need to revisit our assumptions from our more constrained past and rework out understanding to truly advance ourselves, and we're not doing so readily.
Here's an example of another wrong direction: https://www.oreilly.com/ideas/neuroevolution-a-different-kind-of-deep-learning

> [moor](#comment_50_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): so when these people talk about "our chances of surviving an AI", they are actually afraid of the AI "efficiency" and how people would follow its 'advice'!?

No. They are responding to the thought experiment where the Autonomous Intelligence decides to do something we can't stop. 
It becomes more powerful than humans and sees humanity as a problem to overcome or a resource to consume for whatever silly thing it maintains in doing. 
Like making paperclips (https://teespring.com/stores/universal-paperclips) and converting everything including us into paperclips, just so it can keep making more paperclips. Did I mention paperclips?

> [tusiko](#comment_14_1G2W1r5Eh1M81v8sUanDq2Cj4xnaRJurgs): Why do you think that ifconfig displays too much information? This commands show exactly your IP. You can also use:  ip addr show eth0

The output needs to be only the IP you need, nothing else.
$ getmyip
1.1.1.1

> [tusiko](#comment_15_1G2W1r5Eh1M81v8sUanDq2Cj4xnaRJurgs): $ ifconfig | grep "inet 192"Result example: $ inet 192.168.0.113  netmask 255.255.255.0  broadcast 192.168.0.255You can use a shell script to print only the first IP address.Or you write a little script which ends with the output of the IP address.

The idea is to use a command or a few that will *reliably* get you the external IP of the machine which you can connect to for services and used in management. It cannot be a custom script, it must be something available on any system by default.

Looking for private addresses is useless, and there could be a many, for example when running containers. Looking for ethX is also not reliable as different NICs have different drivers and different names, eth0, eth1, en0, lan0, etc.

> [anonimoose](#comment_12_1E5pgBaKNzFU9Loeg7eDGrSkXqJAqbySrJ): I always use  [...]

that only works if you have internet w/o proxies or gateways. not reliable as it's external to the system. plus you have to re-parse the json before it's usable.

there are much simpler ways to do it.

Here's a bad example with a good outcome:

```ip -4 -o addr | grep 32 | awk -F" " '{ print $4 }' | grep -Po '.*(?=...$)' ```
```111.11.1.11```

First print all v4 addresses, then find single IP via /32 netmask, then find 4th column, then remove '/32' by taking out last 3 characters.

> [anonimoose](#comment_13_1E5pgBaKNzFU9Loeg7eDGrSkXqJAqbySrJ): this returns nothing on my machine.

that is why it is a *bad* example. 
take off the last command and see what the result is. if nothing, keep going.

> [anonimoose](#comment_17_1E5pgBaKNzFU9Loeg7eDGrSkXqJAqbySrJ): it actually fails at | grep 32 | :/

ip addr command lists the CIDR notation of the IP, if it's a single one as in IP/32, but that is not always the case, so a bad assumption to make.

this is why it is so difficult to have something that works on every machine identically. While this may work in my company datacenter, it may not work in yours for thousands of machines..

Hence the original question in the topic.
anyone else have a better way to print out just the machines non local IP?

none of those return anything on my machine, Ubuntu 16.04, single external IP,  multiple docker veths

There is a much simpler command. Also, ifconfig is being deprecated.

> [leftside](#comment_423_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): Have u every tried to full-disk-encrypt XFS?

No, but all modern FS support it now. It will use some of your CPU and writes/reads will be slower (10-50%), likely more noticeable on SSD than HDD (bigger difference), but it's not all bad.

Some people will even tell you that whole disk encryption software makes some operations run considerably faster due to compression, improved drive read routines, pipelining and similar optimizations due to how de/encryption is done.

1547272437_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf.body:
everyone is browsing locally.
how is the counter supposed to know what everyone else is doing?
if the site owner was getting counting data, he'd be DDoSd on a popular site.
users write to a site by authenticating with an ID service. so you'd only get people who are logged in.
a JS counter might pick up visits, but they'd be delayed until they were published when someone auths and posts.
ZN itself would need to aggregate that info and share among all nodes.
Trackers might help, but mainly on new sites that need to find peers to download from.
stats are inherently centralized for a resource, so aggregating all of them is what's left.

> [toyata](#comment_49_17mM4YqSx7nMkYcePZB2GWcJBzkogWpqA1): How does GNs work?

GNS zones are similar to those of DNS zones, but instead of a hierarchy of authorities to governing their use, GNS zones are controlled by a private key. When you create a record in a DNS zone, that information is stored in your nameserver. Anyone trying to resolve your domain then gets pointed (hopefully) by the centralised authority to your nameserver. Whereas GNS, being fully decentralized by design, stores that information in DHT. The validity of the records is assured cryptographically, by signing them with the private key of the respective zone.

Anyone trying to resolve records in a zone of your domain can then verify the signature of the records they get from the DHT and be assured that they are indeed from the respective zone. To make this work, there is a 1:1 correspondence between zones and their public-private key pairs. The owner of a GNS zone, is really the owner of the private key. And a user accessing a zone needs to somehow specify the corresponding public key first.

Peer identities are used to identify peers in the network and are unique for each peer. The identity for a peer is simply its public key, which is generated along with a private key the peer is started for the first time. While the identity is binary data, it is often expressed as ASCII string. For example, the following is a peer identity as you might see it in various places:

`UAT1S6PMPITLBKSJ2DGV341JI6KF7B66AC4JVCN9811NNEGQLUN0`

You can find your peer identity by running gnunet-peerinfo -s.

In a decentralized system it may be better to collaborate in a m of n fashion for storage of data chunks, since you don't have to have full copies that way and only m chunks are needed to reconstruct the file and everyone participating only stores a protocol suggested small part up until a resiliency threshold.

IBM acquired Cleversafe which does this, but has an architecture tailored for petabyte+ storage. There was a software version long ago, but not sure if someone still has it.

Recently Minio.io has added support for erasure coded data storage which could be useful to play with.

Nuclear_Battery_Kit

Bring Your Own Tritium Radioisotope Photovoltaic Cell Kit

https://www.sparkfun.com/products/14773

After we caught sight of some very cool folks online making their very own homemade nuclear batteries, we knew we had to give it a go!

The device in question is actually known as a “Radioisotope Photovoltaic Generator” or “Photobetavoltaic Generator,” and it’s a pretty clever design: Glowing glass pills filled with Tritium gas and coated in a phosphorescent material are sandwiched between two photovoltaic cells. The beta radiation emitted by the Tritium is blocked by the glass walls of the pill, but they cause the phosphorescent coating to glow. This light has no trouble passing through the glass and lands on the photovoltaic cells where it produces a small amount of electricity! Commercial Tritium batteries — like those produced by City Labs — cut out the middleman by using betavoltaic (as opposed to photovoltaic) cells in direct contact with Tritium gas. Those commercial devices are more rugged and efficient, but come with a very large price tag (thousands of USD per unit). On the other hand, homemade devices constructed using the packing tape sandwich method are as cheap as it gets, but aren’t particularly rugged.

This kit provides a good compromise between price and quality of construction. We’ve designed carrier boards for both of the photovoltaic cells which we supply pre-soldered and fixed to the boards with chipbonder. We’ve also designed and cast custom silicone rubber grommets which cushion the Tritium vials between the two photovoltaic cells, preventing the cells from getting scratched or chipped and — most importantly — the vials from getting broken. The carrier boards also allow you to choose whether the photovoltaic cells are wired in series or parallel and provide you with breadboard compatible pin spacing for the battery terminals.

So how much power does it make? Not much. The best measurement we were able to make suggests that the maximum power point of this arrangement is 25nW, if you can build a circuit that loads it properly (between 20 and 30nA at about 0.6v). Further experiments show that the battery will — given enough time — charge a capacitor to a voltage of 1.5 volts. Using this battery to do any work will likely involve a clever energy harvesting circuit, but keep in mind that this tiny amount of power will continue to flow for about 20 years — the half life of Tritium being 12 years. It’s also worth noting that these measurements were taken using green colored tritium tubes from aliexpress, your mileage may vary with the color and quality of your Tritium glow tubes. Feel free to experiment! ...

https://github.com/sparkfunX/Nuclear_Battery_Kit

1578738929_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
Oatmeal with added protein powder or drink, then add your fav cereals, fruit & nut combos for something different every time. Dollop of peanut butter every other time. Microwaves in 2m.

Then there's cheap supergrains like quinoa that have a lot of protein and nutrients, can use it as noodles or filler for all kinds of things (get creative), even cookies if you make some.  You can cook it in a rice cooker or even microwave (trick is to have lots of surface area, like pan. even works for noodles, 7m) and store you can it in the fridge for a week using it in various things.

Then there's canned fish of all kinds, chopped onions or pesto and you have a good sandwich filler or addition to pasta/quinoa.

Cream of wheat and the baby wheat cereals are cheap and nutritious, add chocolate or other flavors similar to oatmeal for a creative concoction every time.

Use meetup and event bright to find events that have interesting content and they likely have different kinds of foods.

Working/volunteering part time in a kitchen/restaurant gets you a lot of food  to share.

Portion control is another big one.. you only really need about a fist sized meal, everything more than you need is wasted fat storage or eliminated.  Two of these a day is enough, perhaps with a small snack in between. That means no breakfast needed.

No breakfast because you don't want to 'break' your 'fast' too soon (target for 14-18 hours between dinner and lunch).  The body needs time to spend energy on regeneration and healing and the more time you give it the better, because as soon as you start the digestion process, most of the energy goes there. Avoid being in a constant digestive state. Look up intermittent fasting.

Have fun figuring out how your body works and work with it.

I used to game a lot. It kept my brain agile, fresh and responsive during times of dull work/life periods.
It can be used to learn, practice cognitive and reflex abilities, as well as forward thinking and planning.

As one ages, you find these things are part of your autonomous system and there isn't required for upkeep of skills that you're good at and use every day. One should keep an eye on the ones you don't use and atrophy over time from non-use and find games that help keep those up.

As for the gaming industry, I used to work in it and it was shady AF. Still is. Hence the pirated versions of games are a much more benign (neutral) experience, removing all the paywalls/tracking/DRM/hoops that let you experience the game for what it mostly is with less frustration. You can still opt to pay the developer for the games you enjoy, you just don't have to use their packaging which is often forced upon them by publishers, investors and other contracts, which frustrate end users and ruin a good time.

Keep being engaged, but as with all things, in a modicum of moderation.

1. Email is much more complex to self-host today. You need MX, DKIM, SPF, PTR and DMARC set up and the IP warmed up and cleaned from all RBLs.

 The easy way to do that is with [Cloudron.io](https://trimurl.co/CL)

2. I don't think we actually need a relay for this.. however a simple email notification system would suffice. Be it an App with mobile notifications or an email notification service that lets you know you have a zmail to your email.

3. There is an alternative email like platform called [ConfidantMail](https://confidantmail.org), which also happens to be written in Python and has notifications to a clearnet email for when you get confidantmail. It's self hostable and full on privacy focused with TLS & PGP and unlimited size attachments.
